Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. (Red(High risk), Yellow(Moderate risk) and Green(Low risk)). They would also have to stay in quarantine until the negative result of your test on day 1.    Those coming in from a GREEN or ORANGE zone do not need to get tested or quarantine. The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test. From 4 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay*, Vanuatu.  *Uruguay will move from the Green List to the Orange List as of February 6, 2022.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. To date, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. To date, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    Anyone aged 12 and over entering French territory must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 24 hours or 48 hours depending on the country of origin. The only exception is that people with a complete vaccination schedule do not have to be tested when arriving from a Member State of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See or Switzerland.    Specific rules in place for travel to and from the UK were relaxed on 4 February from those implemented in January. As of this date, travelers from the UK are included in the provisions of travelers from the list of Orange countries, with the nuance that unvaccinated travelers from the UK must provide results of a PCR or antigen test taken within 24 hours of travel, and within 48 hours for vaccinated travelers.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205210857/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements     1/ travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  1.1: for the Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland:  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. 6/2/22    Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128094644/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

6/2/22    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206124352/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/jak-zrobic-test-na-koronawirusa-w-aptece
